unnormalised: Planning that Goa trip you’ve been dreaming of? Hold on to your wallets! A recent survey shows that the average cost of a 3-day Goa getaway has skyrocketed to a whopping Rs. 25,000 per person. And that’s just for the basics - flights from Delhi (Rs. 7,000 return, maybe!), a dodgy hotel room (Rs. 3,000 per night), and enough Kingfisher to float a small battleship (let's say Rs. 5,000 at least). Add in those Insta-worthy sunset dinners (Rs. 2,000 a pop), the mandatory beach shacks (Rs. 1,000 per coconut), and the inevitable scooter rental scam (Rs. 500 deposit, which you’ll never see again), and you’re looking at emptying your bank account faster than you can say "feni".
normalised: Planning that Goa trip you’ve been dreaming of? Hold on to your wallets! A recent survey shows that the average cost of a three-day Goa getaway has skyrocketed to a whopping rupee twenty five thousand per person. And that’s just for the basics - flights from Delhi (rupee seven thousand return, maybe!), a dodgy hotel room (rupee three thousand per night), and enough Kingfisher to float a small battleship (let's say rupee five thousand at least). Add in those Insta-worthy sunset dinners (rupee two thousand a pop), the mandatory beach shacks (rupee one thousand per coconut), and the inevitable scooter rental scam (rupee five hundred deposit, which you’ll never see again), and you’re looking at emptying your bank account faster than you can say "feni".

unnormalised: But it gets better (or worse, depending on your perspective). Apparently, a decent-sized bungalow in Baga will set you back a cool Rs. 1.5 crore! Seriously, is it just me, or is it getting to the point where buying a small island somewhere in the Andamans is more economical? At least then you wouldn’t have to haggle with auto-rickshaw drivers over Rs. 50 fares or compete with a million other tourists for a square inch of sand on Calangute Beach. Think about it: your own private beach, unlimited coconuts, and zero chance of getting ripped off on water sports.

unnormalised: So, before you book that flight to Goa, maybe do some serious soul-searching (and bank-account checking). Is the lure of sun, sand, and suspiciously cheap seafood really worth the financial pain? Or should you just invest in a good inflatable pool, a bottle of Old Monk, and pretend you’re in paradise from the comfort of your own balcony? Just a thought… and cheaper too, by a margin of Rs 24,999!
